newsitem.title: CHINA: China stock indices end down on clampdown fears.
newsitem.headline: China stock indices end down on clampdown fears.

text.p: China's A and B share indices ended sharply down on Wednesday for the second day in a row on fears that Beijing is planning tough measures to cool down the over-heated stock markets, analysts said.
The falls suddenly reversed a strong upward trend during which the indices on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges have risen over 50 percent since the start of this year.
On Wednesday, Shanghai's foreign currency B share index plunged 6.22 percent to end at 87.511 points and its Shenzhen counterpart lost 4.27 percent to 170.74 points.
On the domestic share markets, the Shanghai A share index shed 5.8 percent to 1,442.517 points and Shenzhen's A index fell 5.92 percent to 500.03 points.
"The wolf is coming again," said a broker with a major Chinese brokerage. "The current market conditions are the same as in mid-December last year when Beijing launched a crackdown."
"People think the government is really going to turn the markets upside-down," a Shenzhen-based analyst at J&A Securities said.

But other analysts said they expected the markets to start moving back up again after a short correction. One foreign analyst predicted the Shanghai B share index would hit 100 within 10 days, which another said it would do so by July 1.
"This is just a temporary pullback," said John Crossman of Jardine Fleming. "The big one (correction) comes after the Hong Kong handover."

China's stock markets started to recover from a two-year slump in April last year, and started a powerful surge which pushed them up 100 percent by mid-December, largely on the back of improvements in the national economic outlook.

The rises alarmed securities authorities, who issued a stern warning against overheated markets through the People's Daily, the mouthpiece of the Communist Party, which brought the markets down 30 percent almost overnight.
But in January they started to climb again with investors bullish on the Chinese takeover of Hong Kong at midnight on June 30 and the improving performance of listed firms.

"The authorities have taken a series of measures to cool down the markets and have warned investors about risk time and again but nobody paid any notice," said a stock trader. "This is likely to lead them to take tougher measures."

Beijing has announced an issue of four billion yuan ($482 million) in convertible bonds and five billion yuan more new domestic A shares this year and has also pushed up the stamp tax for stock-trading to counter the overheating of the markets.
Traders said a wide range of rumours were circulating on possible new measures, including the possible listing of the huge number of institutional shares that are currently non-tradeable.

Another referred to a possible extension of the transaction settlement period to three days in a bid to reduce market volatility. The current settlement period is one day for A shares and immediate settlement for B shares.
Other rumours said the securities authorities may suspend the trading licences of several major brokerages for alleged market manipulation.
Officials with the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), the securities watchdog, have declined to comment.
On the Shanghai B share market, Shanghai Lianhua Fibre Co and Shanghai Goods and Materials Trading Centre Co were major losers on Wednesday.
Both stocks hit a 10-percent limit-down level, with Lianhua closing at $0.16 and Goods and Materials at $0.18.
In Shenzhen's B market, Shenzhen Fangda Co was the biggest loser, falling HK$1.28 or 9.7 percent to HK$11.91.
